awd_titl_txt: Systematics, introgression, and adaptation in Western Rattlesnakes: a model system for studying gene flow, selection, and speciation
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite substantial research, the roles of natural selection in the formation of species and in preventing hybridization between species remain poorly understood. In a rapidly changing world, there is an urgent need to understand the importance of these processes in species formation and the impact of these processes on how scientists identify and name species. This research program will study genetic, venom protein, and anatomical data to test how natural selection shapes and maintains species, and it will use these results to test several approaches for appropriately identifying species in nature. The researchers will focus on a widespread and medically important group of rattlesnake species (Western Rattlesnakes and their close relatives) as a model system to study species formation. Many previous studies have disagreed about how many species should be recognized within this group of snakes, and different populations can produce diverse symptoms from snake bite due to differences in venom biochemistry. This study will resolve these issues by developing a new system for naming species, provide new insight into the process of species formation, develop new methods for identifying species, and refine the appropriate medical treatment of snakebite in North America. The proposed research includes methodological and theoretical scientific innovation, undergraduate and graduate student training, establishment of collaborative networks, and public outreach. Public outreach will be conducted at the Dallas and Denver Zoos, thereby reaching millions of public visitors per year.

The overarching goals of this research program are to understand the interaction of admixture and selection in speciation, and to leverage an empirical system to test how these processes may influence coalescent-based species delimitation methods. This research program will focus on the Western Rattlesnake species group (Crotalus viridis species complex and its sister taxon, C. scutulatus; collectively Cvos hereafter) as a study system. This recently diverged species complex has offered major challenges for systematics, yet provides an ideal model system for studying speciation and species delimitation. This integrated study will combine genomic and phenotypic data to delimit species, inform species delimitation approaches, and provide new genome-scale insight into the process of speciation. This research program will also test hypotheses about the repeatability of patterns selection in the processes of speciation and resistance to gene flow and hybridization. The specific aims of this proposal are to: (1) integrate genome-wide sampling and ecological niche modeling to infer population structure and test hypotheses of gene flow among lineages of Cvos; (2) analyze selection in contact zones between putative taxa by integrating niche modeling, genotypic, and phenotypic data to test hypotheses regarding divergence and selection in the speciation process; and (3) develop and test new approaches for delimiting species that more appropriately handle admixture and selection, and apply these methods to test taxonomic hypotheses for the Cvos complex. Successful completion of the project will provide important data to understanding the role of admixture and selection in speciation and vastly improve our analytical methods for delimiting species in the presence of interbreeding across organismal groups. Additionally, an added benefit of the project is the information that will be obtained regarding venom complexity and evolution, which could contribute to better treatment of envenomation from snake bites.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding and accurately describing how populations are naturally organized into distinct species has broad ramifications for our understanding of biodiversity, conservation, and for cataloging life on Earth. In some special cases, this understanding has heightened relevance, particularly when species have major relevance to human health. One example of such a special case is that of venomous snakes. For venomous snakes, a taxonomy that defines species in a way that accurately reflects variation across populations has other ramifications relevant to snakebite treatment because snake venom (and its effects and treatment) is also highly variable across populations and species. This research program focused on a group of venomous rattlesnakes that span much of western North America western United States, and thus have high medical relevance based on their overlap with major population centers in North America. Prior work to organize this group of snakes into species had been highly debated with widely variable conclusions, with different studies variously categorizing these into between two and 16 different species, leading to substantial confusion and inconsistency that had major negative ramifications for understanding how this may relate to snakebite treatment strategies.. Because preliminary evidence also suggested that venom was under strong local selection, and some lineages may hybridize, another broad motivation of the project was to investigate how selection and hybridization may confound estimates of species delimitation approaches, and also to understand ‘why’ hybridization may be occurring, and what impacts it may have on venom variation.

Through the analysis of large genomic and phenotypic (morphological traits and venom) datasets from population across the range of this group of snakes, we addressed the empirical questions about the relationships of lineages and populations in this group, as well as the broader questions about how do delimit species, how venom varies, and what processes led to the current geographic patterns of variation. Early in the project we focused on multiple studies (and software) that address the effects of selection on species delimitation, and that developed new methods for testing species-tree inferences and for applying large genomic datasets to infer relationships among populations and lineages that are broadly applicable to any system.

Publications from this work have provided the first comprehensive insight into the complex evolutionary history of this medically-important species complex, new insight into hybridization and how this impacts genomic variation and venom variation, and new insight into the analysis of large genomic datasets for inferring species limits and relationships (including the impacts of selection on these estimates). In a serious of studies that integrated molecular and phenotypic data, we have completed re-delimiting species for a portion of this group (the Mojave rattlesnake group – Crotalus scutulatus). Ongoing work to produce a final set of seminal papers revising the taxonomy of the entire group is nearing completion. In all, this study enabled the collection of over 400 whole genome sequences for samples across the entire range, which we are integrating with venom and morphological data into these seminal revisions of the species complex. 

In addition to accomplishments across all main objectives of the proposed research, large genetic and trait datasets collected as part of this work enabled an additional set of studies with diverse and impactful findings. As part of this work, we generated the first chromosome-level genome assembly for a reptile (the Prairie Rattlesnake) which has already been used by us and by others as a key comparative resource for understanding vertebrate genomics and evolution, and it continues to contribute as a valuable comparative resource for understanding vertebrate genome evolution. Leveraging resources generated by this work we also conducted follow-up studies that have expanded our understanding of the mechanisms that control recombination in vertebrates, how balancing selection may result from predator-prey interactions in nature, and identified genomic sequences that contribute to the regulation of venom that provide new insight into how novel complex traits evolve in nature.

To date, the project has produced 38 peer-reviewed publications, with multiple additional papers in review and more in development. Newly-generated whole genome and transcriptome sequences have been made publicly available, as have scripts and software for analysis of data. Thirteen graduate students, multiple undergraduates, and a postdoc were trained in evolutionary genomics, bioinformatics, and in laboratory and museum techniques. Outreach in the form of invited talks, conference presentations, university courses, as well as talks to student groups during graduate student recruitment events and presentations to public groups, have helped communicate the utility of publicly-funded basic research to broadly address fundamental questions in biology that contribute to our understanding of the “Rules of Life”.
